column1: Should you restrict reality TV

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: ARGUMENTS FOR:

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: We live in an era of mass culture.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: More people read tabloids than big leaves, and reality TV is the reflection.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Elitism is out of date.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: People are no longer willing to accept only what broadcasters think is good for them.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: There's nothing wrong with giving people what they want.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It is inherently fascinating to see how people speak and behave in unusual situations.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: That's why many intelligent people find themselves caught up in Big Brother and other reality shows.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: They teach us something about human nature and broaden our experience.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: If we believe in freedom and freedom of expression, then we must accept reality TV as an expression of popular and democratic taste.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: No one is obliged to appear in reality shows, or even watch them.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality TV is a harmless pleasure.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Only the pompous people and the snobs condemn him.

column2: ARGUMENTS AGAINST:

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality TV is vulgar and shoddy.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: By creating pseudo-celebricities, it contributes to the uprooting of popular taste.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It is often cruel, exposing participants to gross humiliation for our amusement.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: This makes it the modern equivalent of going to laugh at Bedlam's lunatics.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: The current row on racism on Big Brother shows how unpleasant it can be.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It exploits vulnerable people and has been condemned by the Foundation for Mental Health.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Popularity should not be the ultimate test of what is admissible.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Formerly, public executions were popular and still taking place in some countries.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It is absurd to say that broadcasters should not set standards or be required to comply with codes of conduct.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: We do not allow them, for example, to promote racism or sectarianism or to incite violence.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality TV is devalorizing and should be strictly controlled, if not totally prohibited.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality TV programs became very popular after the endless era of daily soaps.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Probably, the trend started with Big Brother and continues with so many dance and singing shows.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: They played a very important role in making celebrities ordinary people.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: The listeners were introduced to a host of hidden talents that they never thought existed in the country.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Although the channels have become more interesting to watch, reality shows have their own advantages and disadvantages.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Some of them are listed below:

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: The advantages of reality show:

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Ordinary men reach fame: We see real people doing oostdevil stunts or showing their skills.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Viewers come to know them and appreciate their performance.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In addition, reality TV stars become very popular in a very short period of time.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: They don't need a sponsor to succeed in the show biz, but use their talent to succeed.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Social issues: One of the most positive effects of reality television programming is that they address many social problems and introduce people to the evils that afflict society.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: For example, they have played a very important role in strengthening the empowerment of women in society.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: With an active discussion on television forums, reality programs have made people aware of what is happening in their neighbourhood.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Cost of programs: Creating reality shows is not an expensive proposal and brings more dollars for money compared to sitcoms and soap operas.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Early successful career: Reality TV has given so many celebrities who have become great stars to their own rights.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It wasn't possible in the past, but now anyone can shoot in celebrity in a very short time.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In addition, the public is aware of the dangers of different types of addictions, such as alcohol and drugs, in society.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Disadvantages of reality shows:

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Screenplays: The majority of so-called reality shows are screenplayed and everything is carefully cared for.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: At first, people fell for bait, but now the public understands that stories are developed well in advance.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Some of the fights on television are organized to increase the ratings of the show.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Harmful effect on adolescence: The new generation of reality TV celebrities does not thrive on talent but uses sensationalism to always be in the news.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: One of the worst effects of their action is on teenagers who try to imitate their behaviour.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Stunts that are played on television under controlled conditions are imitated by people in real life leading to death.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Some of the shows where candidates participate to win prizes show them in the wrong light because they use wickedness and greed to surpass themselves.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Negative traits can manifest themselves in the public and create behavioural problems.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Abuse Shows: Liberal doses of abuse are launched on shows because directors think that more and more people will watch them.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: This is a huge mistake because the wrong words are taken by teenagers and children affecting their personality and behaviour.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality TV and its impact on adolescents

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It is probably impossible to find a person living in a developed country who would not have heard of reality shows.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A relatively new genre of entertaining production, reality television has rapidly gained popularity among all audiences, becoming one of the most demanding and lucrative niches in mass media.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It creates extremely attractive content, sometimes even addictive.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It would be good if its audience consisted entirely of adults: adults have generally established behavioural patterns, shaped perspectives, and tend to view the content of reality television as mere entertainment.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: At the same time, a significant percentage of viewers are teenagers or even children – and in this case, the global popularity of reality programming may not be so harmless after all.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Although its emergence and development are generally associated with the late 1990s and youth-oriented channels such as MTV, the history of reality television goes back a little further in time.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It all started in the 1970s with the show "An American Family" released on the air (ANVC).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A series of documentaries illustrating trivial and sometimes dramatic events in the life of a regular Californian family captivated the minds and hearts of millions of Americans, paving the way for hundreds of ideological successors to the program.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: The idea of a reality program is somewhat voyeuristic: a group of real people allows cameramen, directors and other television employees to enter their homes or other everyday environments and broadcast their lives on television.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: To make these programs more interactive, producers often initiate all kinds of votes – for example, when the audience decides on the fate of the program's participants via online surveys or telephone calls.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Rather often, even adult viewers rarely consider the possibility that the people they watch are actors, that they follow a scenario, and that the plot and dynamics of the program often reflect the requirements and expectations of the target audience (Screenrant).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In the case of teenagers, they tend to see behavioural patterns and relationship patterns represented in their favorite shows as exemplary, especially if there are celebrities involved – and this is just one of many problems.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In particular, reality television often shows excessive amounts of aggression; this is necessary primarily to keep the public on their toes, making them guess about the results of many fomented interpersonal conflicts.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: For example, women's shows can promote chatter, condescending and bullying in the context of women's behaviour (The MGH Clay Center for Young Healthy Minds).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Men's performances can do the same, encouraging the use of aggression or even violence as a means of resolving interpersonal conflicts and/or relationship problems.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Jealousy, misfit, intrigues, gossip, verbal and emotional abuse are often false in the case of reality broadcasts, and are intended to attract and excite audiences.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: However, adolescents can see it as real, by adopting and reproducing these behavioural patterns in real life.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: And, given how long a regular American teenager spends watching television, that fact is alarming.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: An even more worrying effect that reality shows can have on adolescents is early sexual activity and the use of alcohol and other drugs.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Sex sells is too effective a formula to be neglected in show business.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A large number of television products favour or portray sex in one way or another.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality shows are no exception to this rule; it is not uncommon to see sexual content suggested or explicit in reality shows such as "Ex on the Beach" or "Big Brother".At the same time, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, teens who see these reality shows tend to view physical attractiveness and sexual attraction as criteria for success in real life, or even as means of achieving it.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: There are also reports that adolescent girls watching sexual programming are more likely to become pregnant at an early age.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In addition, many shows depict people under the influence of alcohol who behave poorly.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Some studies assume that teenagers watching such content may feel that it is safe for them to drink alcohol at a young age, or that they cannot be held responsible for their behaviour when they are drunk (Livetrong).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: These two combined factors generate an explosive mixture, adding up to regular early hormonal storms: Needless to say, it can make adolescent behaviour even more rebellious.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In the case of some reality programs, children and adolescents can be not only viewers, but also participants.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: This is especially true for all kinds of talent shows focusing on children's extraordinary talents or abilities.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Although it can be considered relatively harmless and many parents like to watch such shows with their children, there may be negative psychological effects here too.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In particular, according to Arundhati Swamy, a family counsellor and parenting specialist, such shows can lead parents to believe that their children must also be exceptional and talented in certain areas.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It doesn't matter if a child actually has a talent, and his or her parents don't try to benefit from it.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: However, children who are not so far extraordinary in any way can begin to feel less self-esteem, comparing themselves to participants in television programs.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Or, parents can start to exert emotional pressure on their children because of this – and attempts to adapt to too high expectations can have a number of negative effects on a child (Parent Circle).

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Overall, it can be said that reality shows do not positively affect adolescents and children.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: While adults with shaped perspectives and behaviours often see shows as entertainment and do not appear to be significantly affected by them, adolescents may adopt inappropriate behaviours seen on television.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: These trends include assault and bullying, early sexual activity, and alcohol and other drug use.

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Therefore, it is advisable that teenagers watch reality shows under the control of their parents, or do not look at them at all.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Movement of animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The animal rights movement, sometimes referred to as the animal liberation movement, the animal personality movement or the animal movement, is a social movement that aims to put an end to the rigid moral and legal distinction between human and non-human animals, to put an end to the status of animals as property and to put an end to their use in the research, food, clothing and entertainment industries.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Terms and factions

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: All animal liberators believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection, but the movement can be divided into two major camps.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal rights defenders, or rights liberators, believe that these fundamental interests confer some kind of moral rights on animals and/or should confer legal rights on them; see, for example, Tom Regan's work.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: On the other hand, the utilitarian liberators do not believe that animals have moral rights, but support, for utilitarian reasons — utilitarianism in its simplest form advocating that we base moral decisions on the greatest happiness of the greatest number — that, because animals have the ability to suffer, their suffering must be taken into account in any moral philosophy.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: To exclude animals from this consideration, they argue that this is a form of discrimination they call species; see, for example, Peter Singer's work [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Despite these differences, the terms animal release and animal rights are generally used interchangeably.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The division between reformist or dominant factions and radical abolitionist and direct action factions was also described as factional division.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The dominant faction is largely professionalized and focuses on soliciting donations and obtaining media representation.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This focus on resource mobilization, sought through alignment of frameworks with mainstream cultural frameworks, leads to a compromise with objectives.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Actors of the reform movement diagnose the problem as a problem of mistreatment of non-human animals, offer a prognosis including welfare reform and employ frameworks for action that include moral shocks.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was noted that the power of the animal rights movement in the United States is centralized in professionalized non-profit organizations that prefer moderate social welfare reform objectives and tend to be isomorphic [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The abolitionist faction diagnoses the problem as a problem of non-human use of animals, offers a prognosis including vegan awareness, and employs frameworks of action including rational and theoretic focus.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Gary Francione, a leader in abolitionism, formed his approach in response to the traditional movement's emphasis on policy reform.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Members of the abolitionist faction regard political reform as counterproductive and rely on non-violent education and moral persuasion in their repertoire of disputes.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: They consider the promotion of veganism as a low-cost means of creating an antispecific culture and an economic threat to the industrial complex of animal farming [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Direct action or militant faction includes in its repertoire material damage, open release, intimidation and direct violence.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: With this, they offer a prognosis to the problem of the use of animals that focuses on the change of society by force and fear.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal rights actors often reject this faction, arguing that violence is a counterproductive tactic that calls for repression (e.g. the Animal Business Terrorism Act) and does not undermine existing systems economically or politically [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Smaller factions include groups focused on the theory of animal rights based on faith and veganarchists, whose approach is characterized by a critique of capitalism on the grounds that it has led to a massive non-human, human and environmental exploitation [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This factionalization, the researchers stressed, is common to social movements and plays a role in maintaining their health [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Background

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The animal rights movement dates back to the Victorian England animal protection movement, initiated by aristocratic moral crusaders in response to the mistreatment of urban working horses and stray dogs.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Other early influences included Upton Sinclair's 1906 novel, The Jungle, which drew attention to the operations of obscured slaughterhouses; Henry Salt's treaties on the rights of non-human animals; which drew on human abolitionist arguments to recognize the personality of persons considered to be property; and the Alcott House of New England, a community that stopped on the underground railway and demanded that its inhabitants eat a vegan regime [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The contemporary movement is considered to have been founded in the United Kingdom in the early 1970s by a group of post-university philosophy students from Oxford, now known as the Oxford Group [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The group was led by Rosalind and Stanley Godlovich, philosophy graduates who had recently become vegetarians.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The Godlovitches met John Harris and David Wood, who also graduated in philosophy, who were quickly persuaded of arguments in favor of animal rights and themselves became vegetarians.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The group began to actively raise the issue with the moral philosophers of Oxford, including Professor Richard Hare, both personally and in the lectures.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Their approach was not based on sentimentality (kindness to mute animals), but on the moral rights of animals.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: They quickly developed (and borrowed) a series of powerful arguments in support of their point of view, so that Richard Ryder, Oxford's clinical psychologist, who was about to become a member of the group, wrote that rarely has a cause been so rationally argued and so intellectually well armed [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was an article by the novelist Brigid Brophy published in 1965 in The Sunday Times, which played a central role in the movement's animation.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Brophy wrote:

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: We use their work; we eat and carry them.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: We exploit them to serve our superstitions: as we sacrifice them to our gods and tear their bowels to predict the future, we now sacrifice them to science, and we experiment on their bowels in hope, or on mere astonishment, so that we can see a little more clearly in the present [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Philosophers found this article and were inspired by its vigorous and non-s sentimental polemic.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: At about the same time, Ryder wrote three letters to the Daily Telegraph in response to Brophy's arguments [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Brophy read Ryder's letters and put him in contact with the Godlovitches and John Harris, who had begun planning a book on the issue that was also partly inspired by Brophy's controversy.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The philosophers had also been to see Brophy on the possibility of a book of essays on the subject [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: They first thought that a book with contributions from Brophy, Ruth Harrison, Maureen Duffy and other well-known writers might be of interest to publishers, but after an initial proposal was rejected by the first publisher they approached, Giles Gordon by Victor Gollancz suggested that the work would be more viable if it included their own writing.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was the idea that became Animals, Men and Morals (see below).

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In 1970 Ryder invented the expression specism, first by using it in a privately printed brochure to describe the attribution of value to the interests of beings on the basis of their belonging to a particular species [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Subsequently, Ryder contributed to Animal, Men and Morals: An Inquiry on the Malgreatment of Non-Humans (1972), a work edited by John Harris and the Godlovitches, which became very influential [ref], as did Rosalind Godlovitch's essay Animal and Morals, published the same year.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was in an examination of animals, men and morals for the New York Review of Books that Australian philosopher Peter Singer first advanced his basic arguments, based on utilitarianism and by making an explicit comparison between women's liberation and animal release.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The magazine came out of Singer's Animal Liberation, published in 1975, now considered by many as the bible of the movement.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Other important works include the philosopher Tom Regan's Case for Animal Rights (1983); Created from Animals: The Moral Implications of Darwinism by James Rachels (1990); Animal, Property, and the Law (1995) by the lawyer Gary Francione, Rattling the Cage: Toward Legal Rights for Animals by another lawyer Steven M. Wise (2000); and Animal Rights and Moral Philosophy by Julian H. Franklin (2005) [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Thus, the movement is widely associated in public spheres with women, femininity and efficiency.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The public's perception of the movement is influenced by gender assessments; people outside the movement tend to view activists as irrational because of feelings that are too emotional.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Aware of this, activists strategically integrated men in positions of leadership and theoretical production, in order to legitimize the movement and counter popular beliefs over the primacy of emotion in the animal rights movement.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This tactic is based on the popular perception of men as rational and not given to emotion, and follows a trend in the activism of the social movement that seeks to counter traditional associations with femininity and private spheres by focusing on rationality, rights and justice [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In a case study, the targets of anti-hunting activism used class and gender markers to assess the activists' demands.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The associations of hunters of irrationality with femininity and inexperience in hunting and wild nature with white collar positions were the reasons for their rejection of the activists' demands.

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: An analysis of the content of magazine covers from highly visible animal rights organizations (PeTA and VegNews) revealed that most of the featured members were white, female and thin.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: With this, and with the composition of the movement being mainly white, female, and thin, it has been suggested that the animal rights media portray an ideal type activist with such characteristics, and that this can mobilize thin white women while discouraging others.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Racialized, sexualized and size-oriented campaign tactics can also deter potential members from joining the movement.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Racialized tactics include the appropriation of African slavery and the language and imagery of the Holocaust, and have been found insensitive and contested by non-white communities.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In addition, the movement has maintained racist stereotypes about the predisposition of non-white individuals to animal cruelty; these stereotypes have emerged in post-slavery in the United States and Great Britain, where non-whites were considered by law and society to have a tendency to animal cruelty.

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights

column2: In 1992, Switzerland amended its constitution to recognize animals as beings and not as things [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: However, in 1999, the Swiss Constitution was completely rewritten.

column2: A decade later, Germany guaranteed animal rights in a 2002 amendment to its constitution, becoming the first member of the European Union to do so [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights

column2: Perhaps the greatest success of the animal release movement was the granting of fundamental rights to five large monkey species in New Zealand in 1999.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Criminalization of methods of direct action

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The U.S. Department of Justice describes the underground groups of the Animal Liberation Front and the Land Liberation Front as terrorist organizations [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: A November 13, 2003 edition of CBS News' 60th Minutes accused eco-terrorists, a term used by the US government to designate the Animal Liberation Front and the Earth Liberation Front, of being considered by the FBI as the largest internal terrorist threat [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: John Lewis, Deputy Deputy Director of Counter-Terrorism at the FBI, stated in a 60-minute interview that these groups had caused more than $100 million in national damage and that more than 150 investigations into eco-terrorist crimes were under way [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act, the Act that allows federal authorities to help prevent, investigate and prosecute individuals seeking to end biomedical research through intimidation, harassment and violence, was passed in the United States in 2006.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Interlinked activities

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The radical factions of animal rights address injustices against various groups, emphasizing the link between discrimination against human beings and discrimination against non-human animals.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: An intersectional orientation is seen online, on websites and social media, as well as in offline activity.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In Turkey, animal rights groups generally join other social movements by aligning themselves with online and offline campaigns.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: During demonstrations at Istanbul's Gezi Park in 2013, which began as an environmental movement against urban development efforts, various groups of social movements participated.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Among them were animal rights activists who saw the demonstrations as an opportunity to raise concerns about species.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The involvement of animal rights activists in the protests changed the opinion of the animal rights movement's foreigners who had previously considered vegan animal rights activists as elitist.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This has increased the legitimacy and expansion of the network; the animal rights movement in Istanbul is composed of multi-movement actors from the feminist movement, the LGBT+ movement and the anti-militarist movement, and this inter-movement interaction has led to greater coverage of veganism and animal rights by left-wing news sites in Turkey [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Counter-movement

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Opposition to the animal rights movement comes from both corporate and state actors.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The media, agrobusiness and biomedicine industries often portray activists in a negative light, as they describe the movement as misanthropic, sensationalistic and dangerous to scientific efforts and human well-being because of the high levels of empathy expressed by activists for non-human animals.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The media also frequently portray non-human animals as objects.

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Large pharmaceutical companies have taken legal measures to prohibit demonstrators from targeting their companies [ref].

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The abolitionist faction of the Animal Rights Movement often faces a counter-framing by the dominant reformist organizations of the movement that frame radical defense as idealist and schismatic.

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Allegations of antivivivisection, which conceived animal research as facilitating the genetic engineering of food in the hope of grasping the public's fear of genetic engineering, were countered by scientists and animal researchers, who conceived vivisection as medically necessary to ensure human well-being [ref].

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: GAY SURROGACY – SURROGACY FOR LGBT PEOPLES

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Many same-sex couples are eager to expand their families.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: An option for LGBT community members is surrogate maternity, and as family perceptions have become more inclusive, lesbian and gay surrogate maternity has become increasingly common.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Although the substitution process is generally no different for same-sex couples and individuals than for any other target parent, there are some unique considerations to consider.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Read more to learn more about the process, regulations, advantages and disadvantages of alternative motherhood for LGBT parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: LGBT substitution process

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Surrogacy is a popular option for gay men who want to be biologically related to their children, as well as lesbian couples who are unable to conceive or carry a pregnancy on their own.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: In the case of LGBT substitution, pregnancy is most often done with an egg donor, a gestational carrier and an in vitro fertilization (IVF), and the substitution process is essentially the same as for any other target parent.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: However, there are important decisions that same-sex couples must make before starting the process:

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Decide who will be genetically linked to the child.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Unlike pathogenesis, in which the genetic material of both parents is often used to create an embryo, parents of the same sex must decide who sperm or egg will be used.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Some affected fathers choose to fertilize several eggs for implantation using both sperm partners, allowing either or both of them to be the biological father of a child.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Choose a known or anonymous donor.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Although it is sometimes more convenient to work with an agency to use an anonymous donor of semen or eggs, many LGBT couples and individuals choose to work with an identified donor to complete the substitution process.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Target fathers may choose to use a partner's sperm with eggs from a close relative of the other partner, giving both fathers a biological connection to the child.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Once the affected parents have made these important decisions, they should be able to continue the substitution process as any other parent would.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Same-sex substitution laws

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Each State has laws governing surrogate maternity, and some States do not allow or recognize surrogate maternity contracts at all.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: This may complicate the legal process of substitution for the targeted parents and especially for same-sex parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: In some states, LGBT couples may have to go through an additional process to be legally recognized as their child's parents and to obtain a birth certificate designating both parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Depending on your condition and circumstances, this can be done through a prenatal order, full adoption, adoption by a stepparent or adoption by a second parent to ensure that both partners are the child's legal parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: All future parents should work closely with an experienced substitute maternity professional and a lawyer familiar with the state's surrogate maternity laws to navigate the legal process.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Contact an alternative agency to discuss the laws in your state and discover your options to complete the substitution process, no matter where you live.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: For and against surrogance for gay couples

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Surrogacy is certainly an option for LGBT couples and people who are interested in adding to their families, but it's not for everyone.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Future parents should take into account all the advantages and challenges of surrogate motherhood in determining whether surrogate motherhood is appropriate for them.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Some of the most common benefits and challenges of surrogate maternity for gay couples include:

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: PROS

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: The surrogate mother can fulfill the dreams of her potential parents, for life, to complete their family.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Targeted parents have the opportunity to establish meaningful long-term relationships with their substitutes.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Many substitutes are particularly interested in helping same-sex couples become parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: CONS

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: The cost of surrogate maternity can be high, and there are fewer funding options available for the targeted parents than for the adoptive parents.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Some LGBT couples and individuals may experience discrimination or bias on the part of some substitution professionals, potential substitutes or donors throughout the process.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Many of these challenges and benefits apply to heterosexual couples, individuals and members of the LGBT community.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Regardless of sexual orientation, it is important for each family to take into account these advantages and disadvantages, as well as their personal circumstances, when creating an alternative plan.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Additional considerations for same-sex couples

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: In many respects, the marital status and sexual orientation of the affected parents does not affect their surrogate experience.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: However, there are other thoughts that parents should keep in mind when embarking on their journey from the surrogate mother.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Choosing an LGBT-friendly professional – For many targeted parents, it is important to work with a professional who is open and experienced to complete subrogacy for same-sex couples.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: As you consider potential alternative agencies, ask them if they have worked with LGBT clients and whether they offer counselling and support services specifically adapted to the same-sex substitution experience.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Parental Challenges – When you bring your new baby home at the end of your surrogate's journey, you will start a new chapter in your life – parenthood.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Parenthood is full of endless joys and challenges, but a challenge that particularly affects same-sex parents is the possibility of discrimination.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Although society increasingly accepts various types of families, some people still do not accept same-sex families.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Families created through surrogate maternity can face the additional challenge of talking about their child's birth history.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Children often become curious where they come from as they age, and explaining their motherhood to a young child can be difficult.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: HIV and surrogate motherhood – It is quite possible for HIV-positive people to have healthy children through surrogate motherhood, without any risk of transmission to the baby or gestational bearer.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: The Special Assisted Human Reproduction Programme (SPRA) has helped heterosexual and same-sex couples realize their dreams of paternity despite HIV.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: If you or your partner are HIV positive, talk to your professional about surrogate maternity for more information on your surrogate maternity options.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Final reflections

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: Surrogacy is a wonderful option for same-sex parents who are willing to expand their families.

column1: Should commercial surrogacy be prohibited?
column2: This path to parenting allows members of the LGBT community to realize their parental dreams while maintaining a genetic link with their children.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Why should citizens buy from their own country?

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Ramification of support for the purchase of products manufactured only from your own country

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: This article is a research that supports the assertion that citizens of a country should support the economy by purchasing products based on the quality, price and availability of products.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: The purpose of the document is to persuade the reader that the purchase of products only from his country is necessary for his economy.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: In addition, the document will assess the benefits of buying in a country and the consequences of not doing so.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: To understand the effects of local or non-local purchasing, you need to understand the meaning of the economy and how it works.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: By definition, a country's economy refers to the economic system, the labour system, the capital system and the existing system of land resources, combined with various other economic agents.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: These systems need not necessarily be isolated but must work together and participate in harmony in the production, distribution and consumption of goods and services in a country.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Finally, an economy becomes the final result of a number of systems and processes in terms of historical, social, geographical, technological and natural factors.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Therefore, when a country's economy is mentioned, all these issues must be taken into account (March 16).

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: It is also important to understand the various economic factors and their relationship to each other.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: This will enable a person from a given country to strive to play a role in his or her economy.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: To achieve this effectively, it is crucial to know how the following factors relate to the economy: capital, labour, natural resources and technological innovations.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Capital refers to a production factor that is used in the creation of goods and services.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Capital is not used in the production process and since it is made by man, it can be used over and over again.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: In other words, capital is all that can be used in the process of creating something new (Marshall 177).

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: The work refers to the work done by human beings with the intention of producing good and services.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Natural resources refer primarily to the land that is the source of all raw materials that can be used to create goods and services (Marchhall 139).

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: In all economic systems in a certain country, entrepreneurs play a role in bringing together the factors already discussed to produce and distribute goods and services.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: However, this may vary depending on the policies and culture put in place by the national government.

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In this paper, we examine the evidence base for immunization requirements in schools, examine the determinants of vaccine rejection, and discuss the individual and community risks of vaccine-preventable diseases associated with vaccine refusal.

column2: Evolution of U.S. vaccination requirements

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Immunization was introduced in the United States in the early 19th century.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The first U.S. law requiring smallpox vaccination was passed shortly thereafter, in 1809 in Massachusetts, to prevent and combat frequent outbreaks of smallpox with significant health and economic consequences.12-14 Subsequently, other states adopted similar legislation.13 Despite the difficulties inherent in establishing a reliable and safe vaccination system, vaccination became widely accepted as an effective tool to prevent smallpox in the mid-19th century, and the incidence of smallpox decreased between 1802 and 1840.15 In the 1850s, irregular doctors, supporters of non-orthodox medical theories, caused challenges to vaccination.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccine use has decreased, and smallpox has reappeared significantly in the 1870s.15 Many states have enacted new immunization laws, while other states have begun to implement existing laws.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Increased law enforcement has often led to increased opposition to immunization.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Several states, including California, Illinois, Indiana, Minnesota, Utah, West Virginia, and Wisconsin, have repealed mandatory vaccination laws15.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a landmark case of 1905, Jacobson v. Massachusetts, which has since served as the basis for public health legislation, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the right of states to pass and enforce compulsory immunization laws.17 In 1922, the Supreme Court ruled a constitutional case filed by a girl excluded from a public school (and later from a private school) in San Antonio, Texas.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In 1969, 17 States had passed legislation requiring that children be vaccinated against measles before entering school, and 12 States had prescribed legal requirements for vaccination against the six diseases for which routine vaccination had been carried out at the time.13 During the 1970s, efforts were made to strengthen and strictly enforce immunization laws.12,13 During measles outbreaks, some public and local health officials excluded students who did not meet vaccination requirements from school, resulting in minimal impact, rapid improvement in local coverage and control of epidemics.19-22 Efforts by the public health community and other immunization advocates to increase measles immunization coverage among school-aged children resulted in the application of vaccination requirements for all vaccines and the introduction of such requirements in States that did not already have them.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory

column2: Instead of refusing vaccines, some parents delay vaccination of their children.30-32 Many parents follow the new vaccination schedules proposed by individual physicians (rather than those developed by expert committees composed of members representing several disciplines).32,33 Most new schedules provide for the administration of vaccines over a longer period than recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices and the American Academy of Pediatrics or the discontinuation of certain vaccines.

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a retrospective cohort study based on national surveillance data from 1985 to 1992, exempt children were 35 times more likely to contract measles than non-exempt children (relative risk, 35; 95% confidence interval [CI], 34 to 37).34 In a retrospective cohort study based on data for the years 1987 to 1998, exempt children, compared to unvaccinated children, were 22 times more likely to have had measles (relative risk, 22.2; 95% CI, 15.9 to 31.1) and nearly six times more likely to have had pertussis (relative risk, 5.9; 95% CI, 4.2 to 8.2).35 Previous data have shown that the lower incidence of measles and mumps was associated with the existence and application of vaccination requirements for school entry12,36-38.

column2: In a study of the knowledge, attitudes and practices of primary care providers, a high proportion of caregivers for children whose parents refused vaccination, and those who cared for children who were vaccinated appropriately, both had a favourable opinion of vaccines.58 However, those who cared for unvaccinated children were less likely to have confidence in vaccine safety (rating ratio, 0.37; 95% CI, 0.19 to 0.72) and less likely to perceive vaccines as benefits to individuals and communities.58 In a study of the knowledge, attitudes and practices of primary care providers, a high proportion of caregivers whose parents refused vaccination and those who cared for children who were vaccinated appropriately had a favourable opinion of vaccines.58 However, those who cared for unvaccinated children were less likely to have confidence in vaccine safety (rating ratio, 0.37; 95% CI, 0.19 to 0.72) and less likely to perceive vaccines as benefits to individuals and communities.58

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The impact of online sales on the local economy: good and bad

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: With Small Business Saturday just a few days away, local businesses have the chance to attract the attention and business of their target audiences.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Thanks to the meteoric rise of online shopping, they may need it.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Consider these online shopping statistics:

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: 69 percent of Americans bought something online.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Between 4 and 10 percent of retail sales are made online.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: A quarter of the country's adults buy something online at least once a month.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: During the 2018 holiday season, $126 billion was spent on online shopping in this country.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: All of these purchases are purchases that are not made in a brick and mortar store.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: And that means that all these purchases have a measurable impact on the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Is this bad news for local businesses?

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The reality is a little more complex.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping can keep taxes away from the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Perhaps the biggest negative impact of online sales on the economy is that they reduce the amount of sales tax that the state collects and other local taxes that cities and counties collect.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Not all online retailers charge the appropriate sales tax or other local taxes for items purchased by customers in their online stores.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As a result, residents of a state may not pay sales taxes on online purchases they would have paid had they made the same purchase in a brick and mortar store.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: This loss of income is measurable.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: In 2012, according to the University of Tennessee, Indiana lost $195 million in tax revenue for its online purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: This number is almost certainly larger now that the popularity of online sales has skyrocketed.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: To reduce these losses, Indiana passed legislation in 2017 that came into force in October 2018, requiring retailers who earn at least $100,000 in Indiana sales or serve at least 200 Indiana residents in a year to charge sales taxes on online purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: However, this law does not affect small businesses.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: It also does not apply to local taxes and therefore does not fully address the tax gap caused by online shopping.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online sales make it more difficult for brick and mortar retailers to compete.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Because many online retailers do not charge their customers sales tax, their purchases are cheaper.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: A charge of 7 percent on a small purchase can be only a few cents or dollars, but the difference can be added on larger purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: In addition, when customers pinch money or make many purchases, as during vacations, sales tax savings can be important to them.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As a result, brick and mortar stores that have to charge the appropriate taxes may find it more difficult to compete with online retailers who do not add these taxes to the cost of their items.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: When customers choose to go online instead of a brick and mortar store to save money, they limit the ability of the local company to grow.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping takes money from the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The last negative impact of online shopping on the local economy is to withdraw money from this economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: For example, if a customer buys a Christmas gift from Amazon instead of a local company, that money goes to the national retailer instead of the buyer's community.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: This loss of income may restrict the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Less money comes to local companies, which means they do fewer jobs.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Less hiring means less money flowing into the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Less money flowing into the local economy means fewer jobs and less money available for residents.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: They spend less money locally, leading to a vicious circle that can prevent communities from growing.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping isn't all bad.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As with any story, there are two sides.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: While online shopping can move away from the local economy, it can also contribute in some ways.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The key is that local companies enter the online market.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: The main drawbacks of online shopping appear to occur when consumers make such purchases from domestic businesses rather than from local businesses.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: For example, a local company is likely to charge appropriate taxes for online purchases and fall under Indiana law, which requires some companies to charge sales taxes for online purchases.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Similarly, when consumers shop online from local businesses, this money continues to enter the local economy.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Rather than losing money for non-local entities, the local economy still receives money from these online purchases, as these purchases are always made from local businesses.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: This is not due to the fact that local companies must strive to create a dynamic online presence.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Online shopping doesn't go anywhere.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Its convenience means that it is likely to continue to grow in popularity.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Instead of fighting this new reality, local companies can embrace it.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: Through digital marketing, they can build a website and advertising campaigns that bring them to their target audience.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: It is not impossible to compete with large companies.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: It simply requires a smart online strategy, and a qualified digital marketing company like Distinct Web Design.

column1: Does online shopping promote economic development
column2: As the holiday shopping season takes off, consider enjoying the good that an online presence can do, both for your business and for your local economy.

column1: Should there be a curfew for children?

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The movement of labour from rural to urban areas has long been an integral part of the theories of structural transformation: the movement of economic activity between sectors, particularly from agriculture to manufacturing.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: As people move from agricultural work to higher productivity jobs in cities, countries can undergo a significant transformation that can increase not only workers' wages, but also economic growth across the country.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: However, many questions remain about the effects of this rural-urban migration and how workers can be encouraged to move.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: While wages are much higher in cities, as evidenced by the large productivity gaps between rural and urban areas in virtually all countries, why do people still live in rural areas and what could increase their chances of finding urban employment?

column2: The following three studies, presented at the conference, explore these links between rural and urban areas and present key ideas on the relationship between migration and structural transformation.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In particular, they study how seasonal migration between rural and urban areas affects the rural economy as a whole through a large-scale randomized control trial.

column2: By proposing to subsidize the transportation costs of 5,792 potential seasonal migrants in Bangladesh who attempt to escape the annual famine season, the authors identify the effect of an increase in the number of migrant workers on the total number of migrants and the level of income in rural villages.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Sam Asher presented a new paper, co-written with Paul Novosad, on the impact that new and improved rural roads have on labour market outcomes in villages in India.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Rural roads can have a significant impact on villages in that they connect people living there to important urban markets and work opportunities.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Roads allow people previously working in agriculture to look for new jobs that are potentially better paid outside their traditional sector.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The authors are therefore examining a comprehensive road construction programme in India that has provided asphalt roads to more than 100,000 villages since 2000 to see how this affects the people living there.

column2: Industrial parks in Ethiopia: the driving force behind the research programme

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Senior Economic Advisor to the United Kingdom Department for International Development (DFID) and Advisor to the Ethiopian Investment Commission Matt Butler presented the new impetus for industrialization and structural transformation in Ethiopia.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Butler described the massive construction of an industrial park employing 50,000 clothing workers in Hawassa, originally a city of only 250,000 people.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Although the park promises to create a large number of new and better-paying jobs for a population that is still largely rural, the creation of such parks also poses challenges to labour markets and urban policy.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The expected large influx of migrants from neighbouring rural villages will have a significant impact on the city of Hawassa, putting pressure on existing infrastructure and public services.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: He highlighted opportunities for collaboration with the Intergovernmental Committee on Industrial Park Research and suggested that data be available on the approximately 25,000 workers involved in a training program on labour supply and non-specialist skills in Hawassa.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: A strengthened research agenda on structural transformation and migration issues around the opening of industrial parks could benefit not only Ethiopia at this critical stage of its development, but also many other African countries facing similar political challenges.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The world is not a plan without friction.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: However, as in the case of industrial parks in Ethiopia, we must bear in mind that the benefits of urbanization are also accompanied by costs, such as congestion and depletion of local public resources.

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?
column2: Euthanasia can be classified into three categories, depending on whether an individual gives his or her informed consent: voluntary, non-voluntary and involuntary [ref].

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?
column2: Involuntary euthanasia is conducted against the patient's will.

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?
column2: Passive and active euthanasia

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?
column2: Voluntary, non-voluntary and involuntary types may be divided into passive or active variants [ref].

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?
column2: Passive euthanasia involves the retention of the treatment necessary for the continuation of life [ref].

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?
column2: Although some authors regard these terms as misleading and unhelpful, they are nevertheless commonly used.

column1: Should we legalize euthanasia?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Once the cattle died, the vultures fed on their carcasses and, as a result, died of kidney failure.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Vultures once common quickly began to fly towards extinction.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: For some of us, vultures may seem to be of no consequence.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column2: One example is the disappearance of Gypsy vultures and the resulting spread of infectious diseases in India.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In addition, scientists have found increasing evidence linking loss of species diversity in ecosystems to increased disease transmission and incidence in humans.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: However, the answer to the question of whether protected areas really reduce poverty in local societies is still unclear and complicated, and requires a more rigorous assessment.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But not all animals in danger are charismatic.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The conservation of attractive animals such as tigers could later protect their less well-known prey and other animals and plants that share their protected habitats.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: However, protected areas that focus solely on charismatic species could undermine the chances of unknown, more atrocious or more ordinary species living outside these areas.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Instead, scientists have tried to estimate the economic value of ecosystem services: the services nature provides to human communities, such as insect pollination and mangrove flood mitigation.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we provide breakfast for school students?
column2: A school breakfast club is a facility for children to eat a healthy breakfast in a safe environment before their first class.

column1: Should we provide breakfast for school students?
column2: The term club breakfast is commonly used to describe such facilities in the UK.

column1: Should we provide breakfast for school students?
column2: Breakfast clubs generally improve both school performance and behaviour, especially for children whose parents would otherwise not be able to afford regular meals.

column2: However, breakfast is less widely available than school lunch, both in the United Kingdom and globally.

column2: Clubs are often run by schools, but can also be run by communities.

column1: Should we provide breakfast for school students?

column2: Breakfast clubs are sometimes open to children from more than one school.
