column2: Urbanization: trends, causes and effects

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: More than half of the world's population lives in urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: As a result of the continued urbanization and growth of the world's population, there will be an additional 2.5 billion people in the urban population by 2050, mainly in Africa and Asia.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The urban areas of the world are very diverse, but many cities face problems such as lack of jobs, homelessness and expansion of squatter facilities, inadequate services and infrastructure, inadequate health and education services and high levels of pollution.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Urbanisation is an increase in the number of people living in cities.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Urbanization is mainly due to the shift of populations from rural to urban areas and the increase in the urban population and the extent of urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: These demographic changes lead to further changes in land use, economic activity and culture.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Historically, urbanization has been associated with major economic and social transformations.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: For example, urban life is linked to higher levels of literacy and education, better health, lower fertility and longer life expectancy, better access to social services, and increased opportunities for cultural and political participation (UNDESA, 2014).

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: However, urbanization also has disadvantages due to rapid and unplanned urban growth, resulting in poor infrastructure such as inadequate housing, water and sanitation, transport and health services.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Rural migration to cities

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In developing countries, urbanization usually occurs when people leave villages to settle in cities in the hope of a better standard of living.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The movement of people from one place to another is called migration.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Migration is influenced by economic growth and development as well as technological changes (Marshall et al. 2009) and perhaps also by conflict and social disruption.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: It is driven by attraction factors that attract people to urban areas and drive people away from the countryside.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Employment opportunities in cities are one of the main attraction factors.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Many industries are located in cities and offer high-wage opportunities in urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: There are also more educational institutions offering courses and training in a wide range of subjects and skills.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: People are attracted to an urban lifestyle and the "glossy lights" of urban life.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: All these factors lead to temporary and permanent migration to urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Poor living conditions and lack of opportunities for paid employment in rural areas are incentives.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Populations are moving away from rural areas because of inadequate health care and inadequate educational and economic opportunities, as well as environmental changes, droughts, floods, lack of sufficient productive land and other pressures on the livelihoods of rural populations.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Rural migration to cities can be a selective process, as some types of people are more likely to move than others.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: One of the factors involved is gender, as employment opportunities vary considerably between men and women.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Another factor is age.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Young people are more likely to travel to cities, with more elderly people and children left in rural areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The selectivity of migration affects the population in rural and urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: If more men move in cities and cities than women, it leaves a predominantly female society in rural areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Impacts of urbanization

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Although people are attracted to the benefits of cities, the impacts of urbanization are mixed.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: First, we will examine the many positive impacts of urbanization before continuing to describe some of the challenges created by rapid and unplanned urban growth.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Food cities are an essential part of a prosperous national economy.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The collection of economic and human resources in one place stimulates innovation and development in business, science, technology and industry.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Access to education, health, social services and cultural activities is easier for urban dwellers than for villages.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In cities, child survival rates are higher than in rural areas due to improved access to health care (Mulholland et al. 2008).

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The density of urban populations allows government and public services to provide essential goods and services more easily and less expensively (Brockerhoff, 2000).

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: For example, the provision of basic facilities such as fresh water and electricity can be achieved with less effort and less cost per person.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Schools, colleges and universities are created in cities to develop human resources.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: A variety of educational courses are available, offering students a wide choice for their future career.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: People in many classes and religions live and work together in cities, creating better understanding and harmony and helping to break social and cultural barriers.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Cities also have advanced communication and transport networks.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: However, these many benefits of urban life do not apply to all.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Rapid population growth and unplanned growth create urban sprawl with negative economic, social and environmental consequences.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In Ethiopia, the rate of urban growth often hampers the ability of local and national authorities to provide urban dwellers with the most basic housing, water, sanitation and solid waste disposal services (MWUD, 2008).

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Housing

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In developing countries, about one third of urban dwellers live in impoverished slums and squatter settlements (UN-Habitat, 2012).

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Slums are densely populated urban areas and have low-quality housing with very poor living conditions, creating several problems.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In Addis Ababa, a 2008 report revealed that 80 per cent of the city ' s housing units were classified as slums due to physical deterioration of housing, overcrowding, high density, lack of access and lack of infrastructure services.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Slum areas generally suffer from:

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: poor housing with overcrowded small houses built very close together using inadequate materials and with uncertain electricity supply

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Limited access to water supplies

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: little or no sanitation/latrines and no solid waste disposal, which leads to a polluted and degraded local environment

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: inadequate health care facilities that, together with poor living conditions, increase disease and mortality rates;

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: precarious living conditions – slum dwellers can be forcibly evicted by landowners or other authorities.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Many low-income families gravitate to informal settlements that proliferate in and around cities.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Poverty is one of the most critical problems facing urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Urban poverty degrades both the physical and social environment.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: This makes it more difficult for people to escape from poverty and they are victims of the "vicious cycle" that you spoke of in Study Session 2.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Water supply and sanitation

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The provision of water and sanitation services to growing urban settlements, peri-urban areas and slums pose critical challenges.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Increasing water demand in the growing population can increase stress on already stretched resources.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In and around cities, water is generally in short supply and subject to increasing competition from different users.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Urban growth leads to increased demand for water for industrial and domestic uses, which is in conflict with agricultural demand.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: It is particularly difficult to provide water and sanitation services to disadvantaged areas and the poorest populations.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Many people in these areas live without access to safe drinking water and adequate sanitation services.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Even when adequate water supplies are available, sanitation and sewage disposal are often insufficient or lacking.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Tank latrines and septic tanks are the usual methods of disposing of human waste, but they have limited capacity and are not always adequate to cope with the amount of waste generated by many people living together.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Latrines and septic tanks that overflow surface water contaminate and create a serious health risk.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The absence of these essential services threatens not only the health and environment of slum dwellers, but also those in formal urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In Africa and Asia, most urban centres do not have sewers, affecting both the rich and the poor.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: This is the case in many cities with a population of 1 million or more, as well as in small towns.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Waste and pollution

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Urbanization affects land, water, air and wildlife due to the number of people, the number of buildings and constructions, and the increased demand for resources.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: It affects the physical environment in several ways.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Water quality

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In developing countries, including Ethiopia, many rivers in urban areas are more like open sewers (Figure 5.6).

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The lack of sanitation and sanitation systems has a dramatic impact on urban rivers.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: People use rivers to dispose of all their waste from homes, industries and commercial businesses.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Human settlements wastewater contains organic matter and nutrients; industrial wastewater contains many types of toxic pollutants.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: This makes water dangerous to humans for many purposes, including drinking water and irrigation, as well as fish and other animals and plants living in water.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Changes in surface water quality also affect groundwater because they are linked by water cycle processes so that surface pollutants infiltrate and contaminate soil and groundwater.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Solid waste

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In many cities, solid waste management is ineffective or non-existent.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Solid waste management means the collection, transfer, recycling and disposal of all the solid materials we throw away, including plastics, paper and cardboard, food waste, electrical waste, etc.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: It also includes industrial, hospital and institutional wastes that often contain pathogens as well as hazardous and toxic chemicals, which require special care.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Urban waste is often found in illegal landfills in streets, open spaces, wastelands, drains or rivers.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: This is often a problem in peri-urban areas, which allow waste to be discharged due to the availability of open spaces and easy access to central urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: This can lead to the pollution of groundwater and surface water that can be used as a source of drinking water.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Sometimes waste is collected and transported to legalized disposal sites, but it is not always adequately managed to protect water bodies and groundwater.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Combustion of solid waste creates another environmental problem.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: People want to get rid of the waste and they will burn it in their garden if there is no collection system (Figure 5.7).

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Health

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Urbanization can have both positive and negative effects on health.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The main benefits are associated with easier access to hospitals, clinics and health services in general.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: If you live close to these services, you can contact a doctor in a few minutes rather than a few hours or days, which improves emergency care and general health.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: It is also beneficial to facilitate access to sources of information such as radio and television that can be used to communicate health information to the general public.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: For example, women living in cities are more likely to be informed about family planning, resulting in a reduction in family size and a decrease in the frequency of childbirth, with benefits for general health.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: However, urban life can also harm your health.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Poor environmental quality, housing and living conditions are the main reasons for poor health in urban areas.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Contamination of water sources can cause outbreaks of waterborne diseases.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Proximity to other people can make the spread of many types of infectious diseases more likely.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The polluted air can also cause respiratory diseases and contribute to premature deaths among the most vulnerable groups of the population, such as the elderly and children.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Food

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Population movements also put pressure on food supplies and on food distribution.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: As people migrate to cities, they tend to use food purchased instead of their own crops, making them more vulnerable to variations in food prices.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: As the population increases and the demand for water and land increases, it becomes difficult to increase food production in a sustainable manner.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The increase in urban demand, combined with the loss of agricultural land, leads to increased pressure on rural populations to produce food for an increasing number of urban dwellers.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In addition, pollution in urban areas can disrupt the food supply.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: For example, fishing is often damaged by municipal household waste and liquid effluents from urban industries.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: (Effluent is another word for wastewater coming out of a source.)

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: In several Ethiopian cities, such as Bahir Dar, Hawassa, Bishoftu and others, untreated waste is spilled into nearby lakes, which can damage fish stocks.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Economic and social systems

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: The process of urbanization has both positive and negative economic and social changes.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Positive effects include economic development and education.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: However, urbanization focuses on existing social services and infrastructure.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Crime, prostitution, drug abuse and street children are all negative effects of urbanization.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: There is also a lack of social support for children at school and at home by their working parents, who are generally poor.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Insufficient income, overcrowded housing and poor living conditions create fertile ground for the development of violence.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Violent crime is more visible in cities than in rural areas and affects daily life, travel and the use of public transport.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: Crime in the city can create a sense of insecurity among its inhabitants.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: This sense of insecurity in the streets of cities separates residential areas into high-income and low-income groups, reducing sense of community and forming areas where incomes, costs and levels of security are different.

column1: Should developing countries restrict rural-to-urban migration?
column2: During the next study session, we will examine some of the ways in which these problems and challenges can be addressed by examining future demands for urban life and by adopting a planned approach to the development of new urban areas.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Deep Learning for Robot Grasping

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Goldberg's AUTOLAB has been focused on AI for more than a decade, applying it to projects in cloud robotics, deep reinforcement learning, demonstration learning and seizure and handling of robust robots for warehouse logistics, home robotics and surgical robotics.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The laboratory's Dexterity Network (Dex-Net) project has shown that AI can help robots learn how to capture objects of different sizes and shapes by feeding millions of models of 3D objects, images and parameters on how to capture them to a deep learning neural network.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Previously, robots have learned to capture and manipulate objects by practicing several times with different objects, which is a process that takes time.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Using synthetic dot clouds instead of physical objects to form the neural network to recognize robust sockets, Dex-Net's latest iterations are much more effective, reaching a 99 percent accuracy rate.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Watch ABB's YuMi robot helped by Dex-Net 2.0 handle a variety of objects.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This includes objects he hadn't seen before.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The neural network has learned to capture new objects based on previous experiments with objects of the same form.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In the long term, Goldberg hopes to develop a highly reliable robot that captures a wide variety of rigid objects such as tools, household items, packaged products and industrial parts.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He is also very interested in algorithms that can work on different types of robots.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The laboratory research is sponsored by a few heavy hitters, including Google, Amazon, Toyota, Intel, Autodesk, Cisco and Siemens.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Big Data has a game

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The National Football League uses AI technology.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Anyone who watched a major NFL event or pre- and post-game shows probably saw it.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: With the 2018 Super Bowl at the corner of the street, Brooks offers an example of AI that many Sunday sofa potatoes can find relatable.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In the late 1990s, Takeo Kanade, a world-renowned researcher in robotics and computer vision at Carnegie Mellon University, co-developed a system of advanced robotic cameras and algorithms that allow the playground to be turned from multiple angles around the arena and then seamlessly integrated into a dynamic 3D panorama.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: By compiling separate shots in a 3D reconstruction, the system produces a 360-degree immersive rendering of a game.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Dedicated to the Super Bowl 35 in 2001, technology made significant progress until EyeVision 360 was the story of the Super Bowl 50.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: They fixed everything together in real time and built a complete three-dimensional model of all players, so you can zoom and look around in virtual reality to see where everyone was on the ground, says Brooks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It was a burning subject in artificial intelligence 10 years ago.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: How can we get a three-dimensional reconstruction?

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Now it's something you see on TV.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Technology has continued to grow and is now being used in a variety of sports arenas.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Slick algorithms cross a lot of data to give life to Free Dimensional Video before our eyes.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Predictive analysis on the factory floor

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In the industrial field, AI technology is used by the robot manufacturer FANUC in its FIELD (FANUC Intelligent Edge Link and Drive System) system.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: By creating an interactive network of connected machines and equipment, the FIELD system is able to exploit huge amounts of data and draw intelligent conclusions, such as predicting machine behaviour or potential failures.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Customers like General Motors use FIELD to prepare their plants for Industry 4.0.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Deep learning cobots

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Rethink Robotics' Intera 5 software gives Baxter and Sawyer collaborative robots their intelligence.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Brooks says there's a lot of AI in robot vision and training capabilities.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Watch Sawyer takes care of a CNC tower at this custom injection moulding company, where they eventually plan to reuse the robot for other tasks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Traditional industrial robots don't have much intelligence, says Brooks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: But for the future, that's what we do.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We put deep learning in robots.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We try to deal with the variation because we think that's where 90% of manufacturers work (robots) in the same space as humans.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Sawyer and Baxter robots have a demonstration training function that puts AI at work.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: When you train him by demonstration, you show him some things by moving his arm around and he infers a program called a behavior tree, says Brooks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He writes a program for it to work itself.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You don't need to write a program.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Intera 5 is a graphical programming language.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Brooks says you can see it, change it, or if you want, you can write a program into a behavior tree, bypassing it automatically.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This means that someone working on the floor of the plant that is not a programmer can get the robot to do something new, says Brooks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He deduces what they ask him to do and then writes his own program.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The paradigm shift of AI for robot programming

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Artificial intelligence changes the way robots are programmed.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Abbeel and his Embruntated Intelligence team are harnessing the power of AI to help industrial robots acquire new complex skills.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Their work evolved from the search for co-founders at UC Berkeley where they had a major breakthrough in using imitation learning and deep reinforcement learning to teach robots to manipulate objects.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This video, courtesy of UC Berkeley, demonstrates the state-of-the-art laboratory technology that led to spin-off.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The startup uses a combination of detection and control to teleoperate a robot.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: For detection, an operator wears a virtual reality helmet that shows the view of the robot through its camera.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: On the control side, VR devices such as Oculus Rift and HTC Vive are delivered with portable devices that the operator holds in his hands.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: As the operator moves his hands, this movement is followed.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The coordinates and orientation are transmitted to a computer that drives the robot.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This is how the operator directly controls, like a puppeteer, the movements of robotic clamps.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We allow the human to integrate inside the robot, says Abbeel.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: So now the man can see through the robot's eyes and control the robot's hands.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He says humans are so dexterious that there is no comparison between robot clamps and our hands.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: By working through the VR system, the operator is forced to follow the constraints of the robot.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You teach the essence of robot skill by giving demonstrations, says Abbeel.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: That doesn't mean he'll be robotically fast at that time.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He will do it at the human rhythm, which is slow for most robots.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This is the first phase (learning imitation).

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You teach the robot through demonstrations.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Then in the second phase, the robot will perform the reinforcement learning, where it learns from its own trial and error, Abbeel continues.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The beauty here is that the robot has already learned the essence of the task.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Now, the robot just has to learn how to speed it up.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This is something he can learn relatively quickly by strengthening learning.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The operator who wears a virtual reality helmet and holds motion tracking devices telelocates a robot, showing him how to capture and manipulate objects so that he can finally learn to perform new skills by himself using the learning of reinforcement.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: (Photo courtesy of Intelligence Borrowed)Abbeel says their technology is particularly suited to difficult vision and manipulation tasks that are currently too complex for traditional software programming techniques.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Applications include working with deformable objects that change shape during handling such as wires, cables and textiles.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Bin picking is another potential application.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: On-board intelligence raised $7 million in seed capital last fall.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Abbeel says they have been in talks with more than 100 companies to understand their needs and determine if there is a good fit for the technology, noting that the software is agnostic to the type of robot.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We reproduce their installation at our office, then we start collecting demonstrations and writing the code so that the robot can learn from these demonstrations, says Abbeel.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Then we coordinate with the partner company to ensure that we teach the robot to their specifications.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He states that the types of partner companies include car, electronic or clothing manufacturers, contract manufacturers, warehouse and logistics operations, and pharmaceutical, agricultural and construction companies.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We are changing the way robots are programmed, says Abbeel.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We write the code for imitation learning and write the code for reinforcement learning.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Once this code is in place, when you want a new deployment, we do not write a new code.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Instead, we collect new data.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Thus, the paradigm shifts from the development of new software for a new deployment to the new data collection for a new deployment.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Data collection is generally easier.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It's a lower bar than the new software engineering.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Finally, embedded intelligence will allow other people to use this software to reprogram their robots by doing their own demonstrations.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This will allow any company, large or small, to quickly redeploy its robots for different tasks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The brain of AI in the cloud

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Disturbing technologies and new technological trends such as Industry 4.0 and Smart Home are becoming increasingly interdependent.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Progress in deep learning through image classification and speech recognition has been largely based on huge data sets, with millions of examples.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: AI requires large amounts of data, more than it can reside on most local systems.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Enter cloud robotics, a vital engine for today's AI-powered robots.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Cloud robotics allows the sharing of information so that intelligence, essentially acquired skills, can be shared collectively among all robots in a connected environment.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It also allows collaboration so that two or more remote robots, or teams of human robots, can work together to carry out a task, even if miles separate.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: As more and more AI-powered robots enter the market, they will need to be connected to a common platform.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: CloudMinds Technology, a new start-up founded in 2015, wants to be this common platform, identifying itself as the world's leading cloud robot operator.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Robert Zhang says AI-powered robots will need the cloud to make them smarter and more capable.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: (Photo courtesy of CloudMinds Technology)The reason we wanted to create CloudMinds is because we think this is an opportunity to apply our telecommunications experience to robotics and AI, says Robert Zhang, co-founder and president.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We want to be robot operators.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Zhang, a PhD in computer mechanics, comes from mass electronics giants such as Samsung, Microsoft and Apple.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: His co-founder, serial entrepreneur and CEO Bill Huang, was previously the Managing Director of the China Mobile Research Institute where he led the development of the first Android carrier project, among others.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: CloudMinds has attracted leading investors, including SoftBank and FoxConn.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The startup will provide a cloud platform and related services to companies that design and sell robot hardware, just as a mobile network operator provides wireless communications services to its customers.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: While Zhang says their platform will also work well for industrial robots and consumer robots, they focus on making consumer robots smarter.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: For a robot to perform tasks in the home environment, the required AI is very powerful, says Zhang.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: For a robot to prepare a meal or fold your laundry, these are very unstructured tasks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You can't really put AI's ability on the robot.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This is impossible from a commercial point of view, because there are so many different tasks.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: That's why AI should come from the cloud.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Whatever the robot is originally designed for, you can always have the cloud to make the robot more capable and smarter, he adds.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We're still a few years away from the Rosie Jetsons.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Yet some of the AI-powered technologies that can be an integral part of a household robot, such as computer vision, handling capabilities, speech recognition, mapping and navigation, have already emerged from the laboratory in the real world.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museum

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: A museum is an institution that deals with (preserves) a collection of artifacts and other objects of artistic, cultural, historical or scientific importance.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Many public museums make these objects available to the public through exhibitions that may be permanent or temporary.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The largest museums are located in large cities around the world, while thousands of local museums exist in small cities, cities and rural areas.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums have varied objectives, ranging from serving researchers and specialists to serving the general public.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The goal of serving researchers is increasingly to serve the general public.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: There are many types of museums, including art museums, natural history museums, science museums, war museums and children's museums.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Among the most important and visited museums in the world are the Louvre in Paris, the National Museum of China in Beijing, the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, the British Museum and the National Gallery in London, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Vatican Museums in Vatican City.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: According to the International Council of Museums, there are more than 55,000 museums in 202 countries [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The purpose of modern museums is to collect, preserve, interpret and present objects of artistic, cultural or scientific importance for public education.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: From the point of view of the visitor or the community, the goal may also depend on his or her point of view.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: A trip to a local history museum or a large urban art museum can be an entertaining and enlightening way to spend the day.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: For municipal leaders, a healthy museum community can be seen as a measure of a city's economic health, and as a means of increasing the sophistication of its inhabitants.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: For a museum professional, a museum can be seen as a means of informing the public about the museum's mission, such as civil rights or the environment.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums are primarily knowledge warehouses.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In 1829, James Smithson's legacy, which would fund the Smithsonian Institution, declared that he wanted to establish an institution for the expansion and dissemination of knowledge [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The natural history museums of the late 19th century illustrate Victorian desire for consumption and order.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The objective was to collect all the examples of each classification of a field of knowledge for research and exposure.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: As American colleges grew in the 19th century, they developed their own collections of natural history for the use of their students.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In the last quarter of the 19th century, scientific research in universities evolved to biological research at the cellular level, and advanced research moved from museums to university laboratories [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Although many large museums, such as the Smithsonian Institute, are still respected as research centres, research is no longer a primary objective of most museums.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Although there is an ongoing debate about the purpose of interpreting a museum's collection, there has been a constant mission to protect and preserve artifacts for future generations.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Much care, expertise and spending is invested in preservation efforts to delay decomposition in documents, artifacts, works of art and aging buildings.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: All museums present important objects for a culture.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: As historian Steven Conn writes, seeing the thing itself, with his own eyes and in a public place, surrounded by other people with a version of the same experience can be enchanting [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The purposes of museums vary from institution to institution.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Some prefer education to conservation, or vice versa.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: For example, in the 1970s, the Canada Science and Technology Museum preferred education to the preservation of their objects.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: They have displayed objects and their functions.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: An exhibition presented a historical print press that a staff member used for visitors to create museum memories [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Some seek to reach a broad audience, such as a national or state museum, while some museums have specific audiences, such as the LDS Church History Museum or local history organizations.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In general, museums collect important objects that are consistent with their mission statement for conservation and exhibition.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Although most museums do not allow physical contact with associated artifacts, some are interactive and encourage a more practical approach.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In 2009, Hampton Court Palace, Henry VIII Palace, opened the boardroom to the general public to create an interactive environment for visitors.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Rather than allowing visitors to manipulate 500-year-old objects, the museum created replicas, as well as replica costumes.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Daily activities, historical clothes, and even temperature changes immerse the visitor in a slice of what Tudor life could have been [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The design of museums has evolved throughout history.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: However, the planning of the museum involves planning the actual mission of the museum as well as planning the space in which the museum's collection will be housed.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Intentional planning of the museum began with the founder of the museum and librarian John Cotton Dana.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Dana detailed the process of founding the Newark Museum in a series of books at the beginning of the 20th century so that other museum founders could plan their museums.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Dana suggested that the potential founders of museums should first form a committee and approach the community for comments on what the museum should provide or do for the community [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: According to Dana, museums should be planned according to the needs of the community:

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The new museum ... does not build on an educational superstition.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: It first examines the life of its community, then immediately looks at its energies to provide some of the material it needs, and to make widely known the presence of this material, and to present it in such a way as to secure it for maximum use and maximum efficiency of this use [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The way museums are planned and designed varies depending on the collections they house, but on the whole they adhere to the planning of a space that is easily accessible to the public and easily displays the selected artifacts.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: These planning elements have their roots with John Cotton Dana, who has been disturbed by the historic location of museums outside the cities, and in areas that have not been easily accessible by the public, in buildings of dark European style [ref].

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Accessibility issues continue to this day.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Many museums strive to make their buildings, programs, ideas and collections more accessible to the public than in the past.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Not all museums participate in this trend, but this seems to be the trajectory of museums in the 21st century, with an emphasis on inclusiveness.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: A pioneering way for museums to make their collections more accessible is open storage.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Most of a museum's collection is usually locked in a safe place to keep, but the result is that most people never see the vast majority of collections.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The American Art Center Luce of the Brooklyn Museum practices this open storage where the public can see unexposed objects, but with minimal interpretation.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The practice of open storage is part of an ongoing debate in the museum area of the role of objects and their accessibility.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: As far as modern museums are concerned, interpretation museums, as opposed to art museums, have missions reflecting the curatorial orientation through the subject that now includes content in the form of images, sound and visual effects, and interactive exhibitions.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The creation of the museum begins with a museum plan, created as part of a museum planning process.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The process is to determine the museum's vision and the resources, organization and experiences needed to achieve this vision.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: A feasibility study, an analysis of comparable facilities and an interpretation plan are all developed as part of the museum's planning process.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Some museum experiences have very little or no artifacts and are not necessarily called museums, and their mission reflects this; the Griffith Observatory in Los Angeles and the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia, being notable examples where there are few artifacts, but strong and memorable stories are told or information is interpreted.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: On the other hand, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington uses many artifacts in their memorable exhibitions.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums may vary according to size, from large institutions covering many of the categories below, to very small institutions focusing on specific topics, such as a specific location, a notable person or a given period.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums can also be classified into large groups according to the type of collections they present, including fine arts, applied arts, crafts, archaeology, anthropology and ethnology, biography, history, cultural history, science, technology, children's museums, natural history, botanical and zoological gardens.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In these categories, many museums specialize more, e.g.:

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: museums of modern art, folk art, local history, military history, aviation history, philately, agriculture or geology.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Another type of museum is an encyclopaedic museum.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Often referred to as a universal museum, encyclopedic museums have representative collections of the world and generally include art, science, history and cultural history.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The size of a museum's collection usually determines the size of the museum, while its collection reflects the type of museum it is.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Many museums normally have a permanent collection of important objects selected in their field of specialization and may periodically present special collections on a temporary basis.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Sometimes it may be useful to distinguish between diachronic museums and synchronic museums.

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: According to Professor Eric Kilgerman of the University of Florida, while a museum in which a particular narrative takes place in its rooms is diachronic, these museums that limit their space to one experiment are called synchronic [ref].

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: Negotiating with terrorists?

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: We do not negotiate with terrorists is a line that is ubiquitously regurgitated in government rhetoric.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: Why do governments so often and so publicly denounce the option of such a dialogue?

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: Historically, dialogue has always been part of conflict resolution, so what is the logic for limiting political options?

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: To understand the role of dialogue in the fight against terrorism, it is sufficient to think of the possible consequences of an asymmetric conflict between a government and a terrorist movement or group; there are generally three general results: In the first scenario, the terrorist group can become a powerful insurrection and succeed in acquiring power or secession.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: A scenario that has recently occurred in Sudan.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: The second possible result is that the movement is defeated.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: LTTE in Sri Lanka or MNLA in Malaysia are interesting examples in this category.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: In the third scenario, the movement becomes an integral part of the political system.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: This has occurred, for example, in Northern Ireland and Nepal.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: However, in order to achieve such a result, dialogue between the parties to the conflict must be used successfully and when it takes place.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: How to use it?

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: First, it must be understood that terrorism itself can never be eliminated in a systemic manner.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: The expression "war against terror" seems to be an oxymoron.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: Tactics cannot be defeated, even if those who use them can be defeated.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: The fight against terrorism should, in part, be seen as a means of forcing or encouraging groups to take the cover of passive opposition – or to say it differently – the aim should be to transform fighters into demonstrators.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: Bringing the enemy into the establishment is often a political and moral bet.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: However, the potential dividends for peace and stability are important.

column1: Should we advocate peaceful means to deal with terrorism?
column2: Secondly, dialogue and engagement with terrorist movements should not be seen as concessions to the enemy.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Importance of the Species at Risk Act

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The Endangered Species Act, passed in 1973, was passed to end the rapid loss of plant and animal life.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Frequently called the crown jewel of our nation, ESA has been responsible for saving many species once on the brink of extinction, including the bald eagle, the grey wolf and the California sea otter.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: ESA is the only environmental legislation to date that does not require a cost-benefit analysis before taking action, making it particularly effective.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Once a species is declared threatened or endangered, the ESA ensures that it will be protected and that every effort will be made to help it recover.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The Endangered Species Act is not only our strongest environmental law – it also sets out a noble vision.

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy
column2: A wind farm or wind farm, also known as a wind power plant or a wind power plant, is a group of wind turbines in the same location as the one used to generate electricity.

column2: The size of wind farms varies from a small number of wind turbines to several hundred wind turbines covering a large area.

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy
column2: Wind farms can be either on land or at sea.

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy
column2: Many of the largest onshore wind farms are located in China, India and the United States.

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy
column2: For example, the largest wind farm in the world, the Gansu Wind Farm in China had a capacity of more than 6,000 MW in 2012 [ref], with a target of 20,000 MW[3] by 2020 [ref].

column2: In September 2018, the 659 MW Walney wind farm in the United Kingdom is the largest offshore wind farm in the world [ref].

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy
column2: The design of individual wind turbines continues to increase power, which means that fewer wind turbines are needed for the same total production.

column2: Wind farms tend to have much less environmental impact than many other power plants.

column2: Land-based wind farms are also criticized for their visual impact and impact on the landscape, as they generally have to take more land than other power plants and have to be built in wild and rural areas, which can lead to industrialization of the countryside, loss of habitat and a decline in tourism.

column2: Critics have linked wind farms to adverse health effects (see wind turbine syndrome).

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy

column2: There is also evidence of higher mortality in birds and bats in wind turbines, as in other artificial structures.

column2: The magnitude of the ecological impact may[119] or may not be significant, depending on the particular circumstances.

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy
column2: The prevention and mitigation of wildlife deaths and the protection of peatlands affect the location and operation of wind turbines [ref].

column2: There have been many peer-reviewed scientific studies of wind farm noise that have concluded that wind farm infrasounds do not pose a danger to human health and that there is no verifiable evidence of "wind turbine syndrome" causing vibroacoustic disease, although some suggest that further research may still be useful [ref].

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy

column1: Should we promote the use of wind energy

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: Regulatory considerations

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: The Communications Act of 1934 establishes the FCC, which in turn regulates broadcasting media [ref].

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: In response to the payola scandal of the 1950s, the FCC established guidelines, called rules for the disclosure of sponsorships [ref].

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: These rules apply to both advertising and advertising, recognizing that consumers deserve to know by whom they are persuaded [ref].

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: Section 317 of the Act, Broadcasting Payment Announcement Act, is of particular importance to advertisers.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: It states, in general terms, that when money, services or other valuables are paid directly or indirectly to a radio station in exchange for live mentions, the station must disclose this fact.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: For example, if a cell phone provider gives a free cell phone to the DJ of a station, who then talks about that cell phone provider on the air, perhaps mentioning what great service it has, the advertiser must disclose that it is an advertisement.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: Usually, listeners are able to discern radio ads from entertainment content.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: The Communications Act provides for an obvious exception: when it is obvious that something is an advertisement, the payment advertisement provision does not apply.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: However, when something of value has changed hands in exchange for mentions on the air, a place has an obligation to disclose it.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: The Federal Trade Commission is also responsible for regulating the broadcasting industry with respect to false or misleading advertising practices [ref].

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: In October 2009, the FTC issued approval guidelines requiring a clear disclosure of the link between an advertiser and an endorser.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: Under the FTC guidelines, an authorising officer is responsible for the disclosure of any material link with a seller or company [ref].

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: In recent years, there has been a tendency to confuse entertainment/publishing and advertising content.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: Advertisers integrate products into the media so that consumers do not know that they are being advertised.

column1: Is the advertisement harmful?
column2: On the radio, it is sometimes difficult to tell where DJ chit-chat ends and an advertisement begins.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Part of the disagreement as to whether a superintelligent machine would behave morally may result from a terminology difference.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Outside the field of artificial intelligence, intelligence is often used in a normatively thick manner that connotes moral wisdom or acceptance of acceptable forms of moral reasoning.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: To the extreme, if morality is part of the definition of intelligence, then by definition a superintelligent machine would behave morally.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: However, in the field of artificial intelligence research, although intelligence has many overlapping definitions, none of them refers to morality.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Instead, almost all current research on artificial intelligence focuses on the creation of algorithms that empirically optimize the achievement of an arbitrary objective [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: To avoid anthropomorphism or the background of the word intelligence, advanced artificial intelligence can be considered an impersonal optimization process that takes strictly all actions deemed most likely to accomplish its objectives (possibly complicated and implicit) [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Another way to conceptualize advanced artificial intelligence is to imagine a time machine that sends back information on what choice always leads to the maximization of its goal function; this choice is then produced, regardless of any foreign ethical concern [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Anthropomorphism

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In science fiction, an AI, although not programmed with human emotions, often spontaneously experiences it: for example, Agent Smith in The Matrix was influenced by disgust with humanity.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It is a fictional anthropomorphism: in reality, while an artificial intelligence could perhaps be deliberately programmed with human emotions, or could develop something similar to an emotion as a means of achieving an ultimate goal if it is useful to do so, it would not spontaneously develop purposeless human emotions, as described in fiction [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: One example of anthropomorphism would be to believe that your PC is angry with you because you insulted him; another would be to believe that an intelligent robot would naturally find a sexually attractive woman and would be pushed to mate with her.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Researchers sometimes claim that others' predictions of the behavior of an AI are illogical anthropomorphism [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: An example that could first be considered anthropomorphism, but which is in fact a logical statement on the behavior of AI, would be the experiences of Dario Floreano where some robots spontaneously evolved a crude ability to deceive, and led other robots to eat poison and die: here a trait, deception, usually associated with people rather than machines, evolve spontaneously in a type of convergent evolution [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: According to Paul R. Cohen and Edward Feigenbaum, in order to differentiate between anthropomorphization and logical prediction of AI behavior, the trick is to know enough about how humans and computers think to say exactly what they have in common, and when we lack this knowledge, to use comparison to suggest theories of human thought or computer thought [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The scientific community agrees that an advanced AI will not destroy humanity through human emotions such as revenge or anger.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Rather, the debate is between one side that is concerned about whether AI could destroy humanity as an ancillary action in the context of progress towards its ultimate objectives; and another side that believes that AI will not destroy humanity at all.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Some skeptics accuse the proponents of anthropomorphism of believing that an IGA would naturally desire power; the supporters accuse some skeptics of anthropomorphism of believing that an IGA would naturally appreciate human ethical standards [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Other sources of risk

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Some sources argue that the ongoing weaponization of artificial intelligence could pose a catastrophic risk.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: James Barrat, documentary filmmaker and author of Our Final Invention, said in an interview with Smithsonian, Imagine: in about ten years, half a dozen companies and nations in the field of computers rivalling or surpassing human intelligence.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Imagine what happens when these computers become experts in intelligent computer programming.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Soon, we will share the planet with machines thousands or millions of times smarter than us.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: And, all this time, every generation of this technology will be armed.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Opinions vary both on whether and when artificial general intelligence will arrive.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: At one extreme, Herbert A. Simon, pioneer of AI, wrote in 1965: machines will be able, within twenty years, to do any work that a man can do; of course this prediction has failed to come true [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: At the other extreme, robotist Alan Winfield claims that the gap between modern computing and artificial intelligence at the human level is as wide as the gap between current space flight and practical space flight, faster than light space flight [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Optimization that the IGA is feasible fades and fades, and may have seen a resurgence in the 2010s.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Four surveys conducted in 2012 and 2013 suggested that the median estimate among experts for the date of arrival of the IGA was 2040 to 2050, according to the [ref] survey.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Skeptics who believe that it is impossible for the IMA to arrive quickly tend to argue that expressing concerns about the existential risk of AI is not useful because it could divert people from more immediate concerns about the impact of the IMA, because of concerns that it could lead to government regulation or make it more difficult to secure funding for IA research, or because it could give a bad reputation to IA research.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Some researchers, such as Oren Etzioni, aggressively seek to ease concerns about the existential risk of AI, saying (Elon Musk) challenged us in a very loud language saying that we release the demon, and so we answer [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In 2014, Slate's Adam Elkus argued that our "smarter" AI is as smart as a toddler – and only when it comes to instrumental tasks like information recall.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Most robotists are still trying to get a robot hand to pick up a ball or run around without falling on.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Elkus adds that Musk's call for demonic analogy can be harmful because it could result in severe cuts in AI research budgets [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The Information Technology and Innovation Foundation (ITIF), a Washington D.C. think tank, has awarded its annual Luddite Award to alarmists engaged in artificial intelligence apocalypse; its president, Robert D. Atkinson, has complained that the experts from Musk, Hawking and AI say AI is the greatest existential threat to humanity.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Atkinson said it's not a very winning message if you want to get funding from Congress AI at the National Science Foundation [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Nature disagrees with the ITIF in an editorial in April 2016, paying more attention to Musk, Hawking and Russell, and concludes: It is crucial that technological progress be accompanied by solid and well-funded research to anticipate the scenarios that it might be able to...

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: If it is a luddite perspective, then so [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In an editorial in Washington Post 2015, researcher Murray Shanahan said that AI at the human level is unlikely to arrive soon, but nevertheless the time to start thinking about the consequences is now [ref].

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Comparative advertising

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Comparative advertising or advertising warfare is an advertisement in which a particular product, or service, specifically mentions a competitor by name for the express purpose of showing why the competitor is inferior to the name of the product [ref].

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Also called typing copy, it is vaguely defined as advertising where the advertised mark is explicitly compared to one or more competing brands and the comparison is obvious to the public.

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: This should not be confused with parodies advertising, where a fictitious product is advertised for the purpose of making fun of particular advertising, nor should it be confused with the use of an invented brand for the purpose of comparing the product without actually naming a real competitor.

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: (Wikipedia has a better taste and less filling than the Galactica Encyclopedia.)

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: In the United States, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has defined comparative advertising as advertising that compares replacement marks on objectively measurable attributes or prices and identifies the replacement mark with its name, illustration or other distinctive information.

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Similarly, the Law Council of Australia has recently suggested that comparative advertising refers to advertising that includes reference to a competing brand in a manner that does not impute brand ownership to the advertiser.

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Comparative advertisements may be either indirectly or directly comparative, positive or negative, and seek to associate or differentiate between the two competing brands.

column1: Should commercial advertisements be allowed to be fictitious
column2: Different countries have differing views on comparative advertising laws.
