column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Abolish standardized tests for university admissions

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: A new study by the National Association for College Admission Counselling shows that testing-optional policies - a variety of policies that allow students not to submit scores on standardized tests such as SAT or GRE during the admission process - can help colleges improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The study found that schools that do not require SAT/ACT have seen an increase in the enrolment of under-represented students of colour compared to comparable institutions that require an examination grade and that admitted students who did not submit a grade were just as likely to graduate as admitted students who did.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The report also found that the Weighted Average of Secondary Levels (PAS) was a better predictor of success in the college MPA than the test results for non-submitters.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In January 2018, more than 1,000 colleges and universities ceased to require SAT or ACT marks for undergraduate candidates.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The conversation also extends to the level of graduates, where institutions are struggling with the opportunity to use standardized tests, which and how.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In particular, the Network for Inclusive Higher Education and the Alliance for Multicampus, admissions to inclusive higher education, promote and study the effects of inclusive holistic examination practices.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: These projects also explore the most important factors in applying for admission to higher education in relation to success at higher education.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: (Full Disclosure: I am affiliated with IGEN and AMIGA, but the opinions here are mine and do not necessarily represent these projects or any person affiliated with them.)

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: NACAC's report contrasts with Measuring Success: Testing, Grades, and the Future of College Admissions, a recent book published by academics related to the testing industry, which argues that testing-optional policies are ineffective in increasing diversity or do no better than similar institutions that need these tests.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Unfortunately, this debate is outside a serious question: the urgent need to seek solutions beyond the selective admission of students today.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: We must pay attention to the deeper objectives that the selection criteria serve — and for whom.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The use of standardized tests in admissions disproportionately excludes people of colour and other marginalized groups.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The truth is that overwhelming research has shown that the performance of these tests is better for predicting demographic characteristics such as class, sex and race than academic results.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: This disproportionately excludes racial minorities, women and low-income people from selective colleges.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: For many higher education practitioners, these tests are simply the most effective and common measure for assessing students.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: But efficiency can no longer be an excuse to maintain a defective system.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The only result we can expect from this course of action is to effectively maintain the status quo of inequality.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Policy makers and advocates of standardized testing promote the notion that equality requires that we use a singular measure to assess everyone in the same way.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: But a common tool cannot equitably measure the potential of people who have had different chances in life.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Our limited resources need to be reoriented towards finding better ways to achieve equitable results, which will need to compensate for the pre-inequalities of opportunities and resources.

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Are generics really as effective?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: He pays to be informed since, according to the FDA, nearly 8 out of 10 prescriptions completed in the United States are for generic drugs.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Generic drug use is expected to increase over the next few years as a number of popular drugs are patented until 2015.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: What is the difference between generic and brand names?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Is there a time when one is better than the other?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: We spoke with C. Michael White, Pharm.D., professor and head of the Department of Pharmacy Practice at the University of Connecticut, for an explanation:

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q: Why are brand names so much more expensive than generics?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A: -Unlike the generic manufacturer, the original pharmaceutical company must pay more than the actual production of this medicine.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: The Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development estimates that the cost of developing and obtaining market approval for a new drug is $2.6 billion.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: It also pays for the research and development of medicines that have failed in trials and cannot be placed on the market.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: According to the IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics, generics have saved a trillion U.S. dollars in health care over the past decade – a current rate of over $1 billion in savings every two days.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q: What happens when a brand name becomes generic?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A: -At the end of a period of exclusivity of about seven years, the FDA allows a specific generic to be the first to market.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: This generic has an exclusivity period of about six months.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: At the end of this period, any manufacturer who can prove that it can reach the same levels of medication in the blood as the brand name can make a generic.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Generic manufacturers are not required to study people to prove safety.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: It is assumed that if they can reach the same blood concentration, they will achieve the same results.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q: Should generics have the same recipe, effect, side effects?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A: Generics must have the number of milligrams of medication that is included on the label in the pills.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: You can take him to the bank that doesn't vary.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: In addition, the pill should get you in the 10 percent above or below the blood levels obtained with the brand for the FDA to approve the generic, and in reality they usually vary from 3-4 percent in one direction or another.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: So yes, they are very similar in terms of the active ingredient.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: It is possible that a generic gives you a 3 percent lower concentration than the brand and another can get you a 3 percent higher concentration than the brand and therefore the two generics can be 6 percent different from each other.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Most people will never notice a difference.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: According to the FDA, generic drugs do not need to contain the same inactive ingredients as the brand name product.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Inactive ingredients are those that have nothing to do with the therapeutic action of the drug; binding materials, dyes, preservatives and flavouring agents.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: That's why sometimes a pill you took will suddenly be different.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: This usually means that a different manufacturer made this pill that you had before.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: In addition, given individual variations, one person may have an allergic reaction to one inactive ingredient in one generic and not another.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q: Is this true for over-the-counter drugs, as well as prescription drugs?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A: Yes.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: The Food and Drug Administration has very strict criteria, so over-the-counter store brands must reach blood concentrations very similar to those of name brands.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Most people don't notice a difference.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: I strongly recommend that patients start with generic drugs or switch to generic drugs if they are available, as they work almost always as well and can save people a lot of money.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Why throw money to get a brand name when the generic will give you what you need for a fraction of the cost?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q: So, are you still going to get the same effect with a generic as with a brand name?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A: Keep in mind that there is a lot of diversity among people.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: When they do blood concentration studies, they do it in average people, but because the inactive ingredients and manufacturing process are different, they can't ensure that everyone will reach the same blood levels.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: For example, if you have a shorter colon or a disease that makes food pass through your intestines faster or slower, it could make a difference.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Others are simply very sensitive to small changes in blood levels and notice a difference.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q: Are there other cases where you should opt for a brand name?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A: NTI drugs (narrow therapeutic index) can be delicate because the blood levels you need to get a therapeutic dose and the levels that will cause damage are very close together.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Low changes in concentrations can lead to ineffective or toxic responses.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Drugs for seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, thyroid hormone, warfarin (blood thinner) and lithium are all TNIs.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: With these, you need to talk to your doctor about switching to generic, make sure you understand the risks and rewards, and that you are more closely monitored for the first two weeks after.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Among these drugs, patients with antiepilepsy are a unique group that also works well when they start taking generic or brand-name drugs, but within two weeks of the brand's transition to the generic or generic brand, they are more likely to go to the emergency department or their doctor's office.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: For this reason, epileptic patients should not systematically change from one form of the medicine to another.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Some patients will tolerate a brand-name drug, but when they change drugs, they simply don't do it as well.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: The reason may be that even if the blood levels of the branded drug are very similar, what the tablets are made of may vary.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: So, while the average patient does it as well, not everyone will.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: If you are so aberrant, you are better on brand name medicine or another generic.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: I usually recommend trying two generic versions before giving up and returning to a brand name drug because once again, the costs are much cheaper.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: There has been a lot of consolidation in the generic manufacturing industry (companies merge with other companies, leaving less competition in the field).

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: In very rare cases, we only have one generic manufacturer left, so generic is more expensive than brand name.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Supply and demand also occur in generic medicines, and that is all the market is going to bear.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Insurance companies may stipulate that you get a lower co-payment with a generic than with a brand name even if the brand name is cheaper.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Patients with expensive generics should ask their pharmacists if branded drugs are actually cheaper and if they are, to return to the brand.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q: Is it dangerous for your health to change your way back and forth?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A: Most people who take almost all drugs would not notice a noticeable difference in efficacy or safety when changing brands and generics or between generics, except for TNIs, which are more sensitive.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: If you are taking an NTI drug, discuss with your doctors the risks and benefits of changing your treatment.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: For all other medicines, if you change and you have mild symptoms, there is a chance that these things will solve and you should stay the course.

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: If this is more than a slight inconvenience, then you should tell your doctor immediately.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: A computer program that faithfully emulates a human brain, or otherwise executes algorithms that are as powerful as the algorithms of the human brain, could still become a super-intelligence of speed if it can think many orders of magnitude faster than a human, because it is made of silicon rather than flesh, or because of optimization focusing on increasing the speed of the AGI.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Another factor that might deny the likelihood of a resumption of AI is the great difference between humans and AI in terms of the resources needed for survival.

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column2: Physicist Stephen Hawking, the founder of Microsoft, Bill Gates, and the founder of SpaceX, Elon Musk, expressed concern about the possibility that AI could develop to the point that humans could not control it, with Hawking's theory that it could spell the end of the human race [ref].

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Hawking believed that in the coming decades AI could offer incalculable benefits and risks, such as technology that surpasses financial markets, invents human researchers, manipulates human leaders, and develops weapons that we cannot even understand.
